Hello I just wanted to learn a bit more of my condition (I’ve had it for years but now I’m trying to fully understand every detail of it). A condition of Neurofibromatosis type 2(and 1 but it doesn’t really concern me as much as 2), it develops usually benign tumors on the nervous system. One of the most fearful tumors I have (including a lymphoma to-boot) in my C-2 C-1 spinal chord and my brain stem. Since it’s located closer to the back of my brain it affects the area corresponding AKA my cerebellum. Lately after radiation on the tumor I’ve had balancing problems (looking like a drunk person whilst walking) and noticeable coordination problems (like flicking my pencil away without realizing it). I’ve been disabled all my life with a numb and somewhat limp leg (I can move some muscles but not the ones in the front). Turns out from my MRI that my left hemisphere of my cerebellum is inflamed which is normal for post-radiation. I guess the only thing I can worry about now is if I’ll accidentally lose complete control of my balance and fall on the floor but that’ll most likely never happen. Just studying a bit more about how the brain works

TacitKey is proud to be a part of the 25th international annual conference of IAN and AINA (Association of Indian Neurologists of America).

This prestigious conference is a joint association of neurologist with an astute guidance from an esteemed advisory, the conference program unfolds with some very basic, but conceptually new and interesting talks by renowned national and international faculty.

By being a part of TacitKey, you have the opportunity to be a part of this conference virtually. Our users are provided with LIVE sessions of the speakers, given an opportunity to engage with fellow attendees and respond to speaker polls.

TacitKey app is now available for FREE on the App Store and PlayStore at http://q-r.to/banUFU. #IANCON2017 #IAN #Neurology #Tacitkey

Ok so I'm autistic, my brain can do somethings other can't, some bad and some good. I can overlap what my eyes see with what I can imagine which has a lot of possibilities, I can visualize take apart things but If I do it to long and to often I get migraines and the light will hurt my eyes. With my dreams the best way I can describe what my brain does with it, it uses memories and current knowledge to some what predict the future from something simple as me seeing something from a tv show I haven't seen in awhile and then then the next day I check the channel and the tv show is on, or something complex as predicting a video game with very little information such as me seeing a floating city in the graphics of borderlands them a year later borderlands 2 comes out when that happens it's harder to explain, then there's the way I handle grief is completely different because I don't follow the stages of it, then there's the stuffed cat that made a separate personality in my head that talks with me in basic conversations that help with my life and memories, then there's the center obsessions that grow on me and I specialize with such as astronomy, video games and my soul mate, then there's what happens when I have seizures if it's more intense I lose complete control of my legs for a small amount of time I can feel stuff can't move it and it destroys my short term memory the few hours before and after I can't remember, then there my anger I literally become a different person and is hard to control but I can sort of direct so no one gets hurt because I throw stuff

If someone reads this can you direct me somewhere were I can lean how this all happens and how my brain works

The grave was still no more reasuring . Its just an allocated space for decompasisition –To keep the stench of the decaying bodies where its tolarable and then hallow the ground to stop infection- , Just a place for the living to spend or better said waist there life morning the inevitability of a soal bleeding out into nothing. Im dead. In a box over which they gaze caringly as if they will live forever. But my mind is the space between two sheets of glass and the space between atmosphers and planets . Completely void. ‘Admit it you fool. Im dead.’
The coffin is not so sealed. Every once in a while , A worm gets through the side or a develaping hole in the lid, and begins to feed of me and my bacteria , merly as a bigger version of them. My indifrence welcomes them , after all im dead. My darkness comlete , my memory eraized by my minds decay to non-existance. A hundread years pass … but not for me I feel not a secound from now to never . The wet warm fragile found hug my decaying coffin. Always a “Drip drip drip.”, Its gone now. Short-term memory is not mediated by the hippocampus but is instead based in the prefrontal cortex.  We know this because patients with damage to the hippocampus perform normally on tests of short-term (7 +/- 2) but are unable to form new, explicit long-term memories (a condition known as anterograde amnesia).  In contrast, patients with damage to the dorsolateral region of the prefrontal cortex perform poorly on tests of STM  but can explicitly remember prior events (although in a disorganized fashion).

Good educational video, except for the "evolutionary spins" on a few things:

- "The mesencephalon... thanks to 'evolution', remains undivided."
Why "thanks to evolution?" I'm sorry, but exactly what role did "evolution" play there? I know this whole video is an overview on the CNS but throwing out little evolutionary comments like that serve ZERO purpose - the explanation would have been complete without it.

- "The cerebrum grew, through evolutionary time, and got more massive and the skull didn't exactly keep up... so to squeeze all the nervous tissue in the skull the brain then (all on its own) formed gyri & sulci, to fit (all the brain matter) into the skull."
So, which came first? The chicken or the egg? The brain growth or the gyri & sulci? One couldn't have happened first which would then set off a second reaction to the first event. All of this needed to occur all at the same time. Otherwise, how did "the first brain evolution" actually occur? The brain grows (skull doesn't) so it just forms these ridges and grooves (gyri & sulci) to accommodate itself?

PUH-LEASE!

Apart from that evolutionary bizzo, again, a good educational video.

It's funny how we say: "my brain, the brain, his/her brain", when really we're just brains that control human bodies. So instead of saying "my brain" as if I'm not apart of it, it's really just "me" because I am a brain. If you wanna get "weirder". Your brain or you are made up of millions of brain cells. When you make a decision, let's say to watch this video, millions of your brain cells that control decision making, made split second decisions on what you should do. They voted and unanimously agreed that this was the best choice for you. However, is it "you". Imagine if you have a tough decision to make you're brain cells vote and the majority side wins. Kind of like a congress.

Basically, it's not you who made a decision it's you all. You guys decided to read this comment to this point. Whatever YOU GUYS do from here will be influenced subconsciously, and this subconscious effect acts like big business or interest groups that influence individual politicians to behave differently or favor certain bills. Most likely you guys, who are brain cells are collectively feeling weird, that is a subconscious stimulus. However you choose to act, and whatever feelings you have will be voted on and decided in a matter of seconds. Even as you brain cells read this last sentence you've voted to finish this post.﻿

Though I have MS, it doesn't really impact my day to day life other than taking daily medication (no longer a shot, thank goodness!) and some numbness on the bottom of my foot and on the finger tips of one hand.  I have 3 or 4 lesions in my brain that were never noticed until after my spinal lesions caused the numbness and I had an MRI to find out why. However, I noticed that I was dropping vowels when I was writing.  I am right handed and to cure the numbness in my left fingers, I started practicing using chop sticks and practicing writing with my left hand.  Dang if the vowels didn't come back and I haven't had a problem with them since.

I'm a music therapist and I use singing as a main technique for speech therapy. It works. I also focus on the part of the brain responsible for reflex to help people with brain damage to improve the time it takes to make sound. This is sometimes known as Neuroplasticity. If you know someone with a this type of brain damage try playing a song they would be very familiar with and see if they can sing it without having to try. That would be a positive sign.

The outer layer of the cerebrum is actually called the neocortex. The cerebral cortex is really just another name for the cerebrum.

Also, no mention of the basal ganglia? It interacts heavily with the frontal lobe (and to a small extent the occipital lobe), and is extremely important in decision making, emotion, and motor and eye movements.
